G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Lisa Thompson, and respectfully submits this Complaint for Modification of the custody order entered on January 15, 2019, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and other applicable Massachusetts law.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985): Affirming that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly states that the governing standard in both custody and removal decisions is the best interests of the child, and it evaluates the custody award to the mother expressly under that standard. The court interprets the removal statute’s “upon cause shown” language to mean that removal must be in the child’s best interests and emphasizes that the child’s best interests remain the paramount concern, even while recognizing that the custodial parent’s interests are relevant. Thus the case clearly affirms that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody-related determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”}

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001): Holding that custody arrangements must reflect the current realities of the child’s and parents’ circumstances.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on two related points: (1) a custody modification must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the proposed move, and (2) a relocation analysis must consider the custodial parent’s ‘real advantage’ and the collective Yannas factors. The court does not state a general rule that custody arrangements must reflect the current realities of the child’s and parents’ circumstances; instead, it emphasizes deference to the prior custody judgment and rejects using a court-imposed temporary arrangement as the basis for a permanent custody change. Thus, the case does not clearly stand for the broad proposition claimed.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’… There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements….”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981): Reiterating that a material change in circumstances creates grounds for custody or visitation modification.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion is about modification of alimony and child support under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 37, not about custody or visitation. It reiterates that a petitioner must show a material change in circumstances to modify support/alimony, but it does not discuss or set standards for custody or visitation modification. Thus, citing this case specifically for custody/visitation modification is inaccurate, though it does support the general material-change standard for financial orders.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances.”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976): Addressing the importance of a child’s educational stability in custody matters.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on general best-interest-of-the-child principles and the deference owed to the probate judge’s custody determination, primarily in the context of conflicting parental philosophies and harmful visitation conflicts. It does not discuss the concept of educational stability (such as continuity of schooling, school placement, or minimizing educational disruption) as a distinct or emphasized factor in custody decisions. Any references to “education” are incidental and not developed as a legal principle about educational stability in custody matters.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and the wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006): Confirming that academic and developmental progress can be a factor in determining best interests.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly treats the children’s academic and developmental situation as central to the best-interests analysis in the removal context. The court affirms the trial judge’s reliance on the older child’s learning disabilities, his social development, and the comparative quality of the school systems, concluding that the move would be detrimental to his socialization and education. This confirms that academic and developmental progress are appropriate and important factors in determining best interests.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The Chelmsford school district has initiated a student accommodation plan for the child, and his middle school has established an ‘active and effective support system for him.’ The judge found that the child is making ‘great strides’ both socially and educationally in his middle school. … [T]he move to New Hampshire would be ‘detrimental’ to the older child’s socialization and education. … She made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them… From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

McMahon v. McMahon, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 50.raw_text: McMahon v. McMahon, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 504 (1991)
McMahon v. McMahon, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 50.proposition: McMahon v. McMahon, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 504 (1991): Citing the importance of eliminating undue stress and disruption to a child in custody arrangements.
McMahon v. McMahon, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 50.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns division of military retirement benefits and domicile/jurisdiction issues under the Uniformed Services Former Spouses’ Protection Act. It does not discuss child custody, the welfare of a child, or the need to avoid undue stress or disruption to a child in custody arrangements. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for that specific custody-related proposition.
McMahon v. McMahon, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 50.relevant_excerpt: At the time of the judgment, the judge made findings of fact which show that she considered all factors relevant under G. L. c. 208, § 34. Those findings have a solid basis in the evidence and support the judge’s rationale for the division. … We see no abuse of discretion in the judge’s decision to afford weight to the facts that during the marriage Richard advanced his career and education by spending significant periods of time away from his family, that as a result of his personal advancement, he has a greater opportunity to acquire income and assets in the future, and that Richard had dissipated marital assets in maintaining a relationship with another woman while married to Susan.

Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 713 (2011)
Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 713 (2011): Emphasizing that adjustments to parenting time may be necessary when logistics prohibit a functional schedule.
Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion is primarily a removal/relocation case, not a general parenting-time case, but in applying the Yannas best-interests analysis the court expressly notes that the judge revised the visitation schedule to account for the logistical realities created by the move. The court approves adjusting the parenting schedule to increase the father’s time during weekends, summer, and vacations and to limit travel time, recognizing that logistical constraints of distance require modifying parenting time to maintain a functional schedule. Thus it provides some support—though indirectly—for the idea that parenting time must be adjusted when logistics make the prior schedule impractical.
Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The judge also considered the impact of removal on the children’s relationship with the father and the deleterious effects of increased travel, and adjusted the visitation schedule to increase the children’s time spent with the father during the weekends, summer, and other school vacations, as well as to limit the travel time between the parties’ homes.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981): Discussing the significance of routine and stability for a child’s psychological well-being.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion does not use the specific words “routine” or “stability,” but it clearly emphasizes minimizing disruption, providing a “healthy environment for the growth and development of the children,” and avoiding arrangements (like joint custody in a high‑conflict situation) that would invite “continued warfare and conflict.” This reflects an underlying concern for psychological well-being through a stable, low-conflict custodial arrangement, which is close to the claimed proposition, though not phrased in those exact terms.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children. … [B]ecause the parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing … an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare.”

Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924 (199.raw_text: Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924 (1998)
Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924 (199.proposition: Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924 (1998): Allowing modification of orders when there is a need to protect the child’s health and best interests.
Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion in Carr v. Carr concerns an initial custody determination and the standard a judge applies (best interests, with broad trial‑court discretion). It does not discuss modification of prior custody or visitation orders, nor does it frame any rule about modifying orders specifically to protect a child’s health or best interests. The proposition therefore mischaracterizes the case’s holding and scope.
Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924 (199.relevant_excerpt: “In any event, in Kendall v. Kendall, 426 Mass. 238 (1997), decided after judgment entered in this case, the Supreme Judicial Court reaffirmed the principle set forth in the Vilakazi decision that the custody of a child is to be determined by the ‘happiness and welfare of the child’ (371 Mass. at 409) and rests within the discretion of the trial judge… In deciding that that parent should be the mother, he properly considered several factors…”
